question: 久しぶり
sourceMnemonic: This is kind of a "set phrase" in Japanese, though we're going to treat it like a vocab word here (because it's so common and useful!). You know that <kanji><ja>久</ja></kanji> means "long time" - so now let's pay attention to the kana: <ja>しぶり</ja>. Just imagine that <reading>she buri</reading>ed you alive, then a few days later came back to dig you up. The first thing she says is "<vocabulary>LONG TIME NO SEE!</vocabulary>"
sourceReadingMnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned <ja>久しい</ja>. It's the same one!
